title: An iPhone 11 Review for Owners of Aging iPhones
text:
This year I’ve written two iPhone reviews. Read this if you have an older iPhone and are unsure about what comes next. If you’d also like to know more about my testing of the new iPhone 11 and iPhone 11 Pro models—particularly their camera and battery life—go here.

Gather ’round for a tale of two iPhone owners.

Sir Upgrades-A-Lot owns an iPhone XS and is salivating over the $1,099 iPhone 11 Pro Max. He just can’t wait to test the new ultra-wide camera and caress the new textured matte midnight-green glass finish.

Then there’s Sir Sixer. His old iPhone is held together with duct tape and chewing gum, and Apple has publicly announced it will no longer be making software for it.

I had a tough time reviewing the new iPhone 11, 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max. With their significant boost in battery life and new camera tricks, they serve Apple’s most dedicated audience, but alone they don’t address the needs of those who wrote us by the hundreds in recent weeks, people who don’t know what to do when upgrading their iPhone 7 or 6…or even 5.

With Apple’s yearly upgrade hypecycle, it’s easy to lose track of the reality that most people are holding on to their phones for longer and longer—sometimes four or five years. And some of the better options for those people aren’t the brand new $1,000-and-up Pro phones, but cut-rate models from prior years. Meanwhile, with a jump to 5G likely for 2020, they might want to pick something that either doesn’t cost too much or will hold its trade-in value.

Going from an iPhone 6 to an iPhone 11 means big improvements in everything from the screen to the battery to the camera. You will lose that headphone jack but all new iPhones come with headphones that plug into the Lightning port. Photo: David Chow for The Wall Street Journal

After combing through many, many reader emails with my editor Wilson Rothman and testing the phones for the past week, I’ve boiled a few things down and tried to write up some guidance for each of you.

Are you....

…the iPhone 6 owner who doesn’t know where to go next?

Here’s the great news for you: Whatever you pick, everything—from the screen to the battery to the camera—will be so much better.

Since you’re someone who holds on to a phone for so long, you should start with the newest models. For most, I recommend the $699 iPhone 11. It has great battery life and all the new camera tricks (minus the telephoto lens of the Pro models). I decided to shoot a bunch of photos with the iPhone 6 vs. the iPhone 11 over the past week and the low-light shots, especially, show us how far the technology has come.

The leaps in low-light photography are clear when you compare the iPhone 6S with the iPhone 11’s new night mode. Photo: Joanna Stern/The Wall Street Journal

If you’re looking to save $100, the now-$599 iPhone XR is really the same phone, with an older processor, a bit less battery life and one fewer camera on the back.

If you’re coming from an iPhone 6 Plus, the iPhone 11 (and XR) won’t feel much bigger to you. If you don’t want so much phone, the $999 iPhone 11 Pro has a smaller footprint but a fancier screen and cameras.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS What features matter to you most as you consider an upgrade? How much will price influence your final decision? Join the conversation below.

…the iPhone 6, 7 or 8 owner with concerns about Face ID?

I’ve heard many people say they don’t want to move to Apple’s facial-recognition system. If that’s you, I hope to set your mind at ease: I find Face ID to be faster and more convenient than the fingerprint sensor. Apple’s had three years to work out the kinks and Face ID is even faster on the new iPhone 11 models. Also, remember that this all happens on your phone: Apple Inc. doesn’t secretly upload your face every time you unlock your screen.

A slightly bigger challenge comes in learning the new gestures to navigate a phone without the home button but I have faith in you. I also made this handy manual when I reviewed the iPhone X, the first phone to go home-button-free.

Some people who are used to the older iPhone Touch ID fingerprint scanner are concerned about making the jump to Face ID facial recognition, but the latter is actually faster and more convenient in many cases. Photo: David Chow for The Wall Street Journal

If you absolutely do not want to give it a try, your only remaining iPhone option is the $449-and-up iPhone 8. Perhaps you’ll want to stockpile them!

…the iPhone SE owner who really wants a smaller phone?

I wish I had better news for all you small-phone lovers, but all signs point to Apple forgetting about this phone soon. Your best choice is the iPhone 8 too. I did some retesting of the iPhone 8’s camera this past week. Sadly, you don’t get portrait mode on the smaller model, but it takes quite respectable photos—even in low light. You also get wireless charging, which all new iPhones now have.

…the iPhone X owner considering holding out for one more year?

You, my iPhone X-owning friend, have it hardest of all. You’ve got the most modern design but you’re now behind on battery life, Face ID improvements and camera tricks. Yet if you upgrade this go-round, you might miss out on next year’s expected big refresh with 5G and more.

If you can live with the current phone, hang onto it for another year. If not, go with the iPhone 11 and skip the iPhone 11 Pro. You might miss that telephoto camera and OLED screen, but you can put $300 toward next year’s upgrade, and enjoy some extra battery life in the meantime.

The ultra-wide camera on the iPhone 11 lets you take very artistic photos without much movement. Photo: Joanna Stern/The Wall Street Journal

…the iPhone owner who has lost faith in Apple?

The vast majority of people who wrote to us this past week are wondering which iPhone to replace their current iPhone with. But some—upset about ever increasing screen sizes and the yearly upgrade roller coaster—suggested they might jump to Android.

There’s no question there are high-quality Android options, particularly the Galaxy S and Note lines from Samsung and the Pixel line from Google, which deliver performance that’s on par with iPhones. But when you stray from the flagships, in search of a smaller screen, or cheaper choices, or early 5G access, or a new folding form factor, you enter into early-adopter territory that’s right for some but not for all.

So proceed with caution. Walled gardens like Apple’s might pen you in, but they can also keep out the lions and tigers and bears. For a demonstration of those pros and cons, see the new “Sign in with Apple” feature.

description: In addition to a review of Apple’s new iPhone 11 models, our columnist has some advice for people looking to trade in their old iPhone. After all, the latest and greatest aren’t your only options.
